Ooaman

More often than not, I would choose to hear an electric guitar. Acoustic is okay but it has been really hard for me to get into listening to Acoustic. However, I have gradually gotten into the whole idea of listening to an acoustic guitar. I think it was that I hear acoustic and I think of folk music. By folk music, I'm referring to the style of Bob Dylan. Now I have no problem with Bob Dylan. He doesn't exactly have the best voice but if you are able to understand the words, he is a good musician. (He is also one artist that I can impersonate.:)) Now I would say that I can take acoustic but I think what made it hard for me to really catch on is (thinking of folk music) is that it seemed that the music was soooooooo sloooooooow.
 A specific album I'm thinking of right now is Bruce Springsteen's Nebraska. That album, besides him singing, was just acoustic guitar and harmonica. And where I'm usually a big fan of the Boss, that was such a hard album to get into. But there's other songs that are on acoustic guitars by the Boss that I like and didn't realize that it was acoustic. So I guess it's more of a genre that I didn't like as apposed to the guitar.
 But down to business, I do prefer electric over acoustic. And that is purely personal taste at this point in time. But both can be hooked up to an amp.emoticon_cool

Acoustic is my preference. It requires no power other than that of the fingers and it doesn't enhance the lack of talent of the player as electronic devices can do.
 
 Anybody see Donnie Benise last night on TV? Magic fingers if I ever saw any.
 
 I play a Gallagher 10-string and an Alvarez, both with acoustic pickups. They make all the volume I could ever need. The Peavy makes either of them audible from a great distance and there's never the sound of an overdriven amplifier or the screeching associated with heavy metal.

 10 string?! I just looked it up to see a picture of one, but I'd never heard of a 10 string guitar until you said something.
PM me your email and I'll send you a couple of pictures of mine (guitar) 
 How does playing it work? 
 Just like a 12 standard twelve string except two strings are missing. 
What's the tuning? 
Just like a 12 string except 2 strings are missing. 
Is the idea to have a deeper bass range or a higher upper range?
No. It has the same tuning as 12 string except one B and one little E are not there. It has all the same open strings without the duplication of those two strings.
 Can you still play many chords with it...
yes
... or is it primarily designed for picking?
I use both techniques (strumming and finger picking). To catch the little strings (those which are an octave higher than the 6 strings on a standard guitar) I pick down with the thumb. To catch the standard strings, I pick up with the fingers. Depending on the picking finger sequence, there are several sustained note progressions that can be played on it that absolutely cannot be played on a 6 string guitar.
 I ask only because the neck is so wide in the pictures I saw. 
 I think the neck on this one is one and five eighths inches...rather narrow compared to some concert guitars.
Sorry to overload you with questions, ...
Not to worry. I'm been known to multiplex.
...it's just that I am a music lover ang guitarist and I've never heard of such a thing.
I hadn't either until I played my old Epiphone 12 string with some broken strings and decided to have one made that way.
 
 Mine's actually not nearly as mindboggling as the 13 string guitar I saw played on the Eric Clapton Guitar Festival some time back. It had 13 distinct open pitches. The operator of it was phenominal.
billsco

I have a preference for electric guitars. As a little kid I remember the neighbor coming over one Saturday night with a Fender electric and a Sears Silvertone amp. It was magic. I was supposed to be asleep upstairs but instead I sat on the steps taking in the wonderful sound. I knew I would be a guitar player someday. 
 
 Chet Atkin's great body of work is a testament to the versatility and sounds capable in an electric guitar. During his early period in the '50's he used a D'Angelico guitar. You can hear it here. This guitar was wonderfully clean with great sustain. (Incidentally, he recorded that whole album in one day. That's what we cats call being in the groove.) 
 
 In the 60's to the '80's began his wonderful association with Gretsch. For most of that period he recorded with his legendary 1959 Gretsch Country Gentleman. A sweeter sounding guitar has never been captured on tape.
 Here's an album that captures that wonderful sound, and is in the Christmas spirit. 
 
 In the acoustic realm, he recorded a lot with a DelVecchio. It is a Brazilian guitar with a built in resonator. I frankly never cared for the sound. It has a harsh metallic tone, IMO. Though he said it was his favorite to play, it and most other DelVecchios are plagued by poor workmanship and, if I remember, the company has gone out of business. Scroll down on this album and select "Theme From Love Story" for a listen to the DelVecchio.
 
 My favorite guitar, the one I'll never part with, is a 1968 Gretsch Country Gentleman.

billsco

Oops, I was afraid my links might not work.
 
 First you'll have to click Chet Atkins in the opening page.
 
 For the D'Angelico, scroll down to the year 1956 and select "Finger Style Guitar".
 
 For the Gretsch, scroll down to 1961 and select "Christmas with Chet Atkins".
 (Or for a real treat scroll down to 1975 and listen to "Chester and Lester". That's Les Paul, the one who invented the electric guitar.) 
 
 For the DelVecchio, scroll down to 1971 and select "For the Good Times." The guitar is played on "Theme From Love Story".

My favorite strings are either D'addario, or Ernie Ball.
